physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. The letter was originally written in type, with a several strikeouts and additions on the first page, and a single strikeout and addition on the second page, all in blue pen. The letter was written on Amy Lowell's stationery.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: I apologise, but it was not because I did not read what you wrote, becausebut I read it wrong. I thought that the slip said "Harriet read this," reading "Harriet" for "hadn't". Indeed I always read everything you write; most carefully, becausebut I admit I am rotten about reading hand-writing.

I did not ask you to send me back the manuscript of my review on Miss Norton's book, merely the proof, so I return it exactly as it was with only two changes which you may take out if you want to,. fFirsty,, the quotation about the "teak forest." I do think itis too funny. to leave on T - | . Second, I also prefer the repetition of "Miss Norton" in the second paragraph as a little more formal where it is used, so I have put that back. If it makes you very unhappy, why take it out. I regret your insistence upon my leaving out the last paragraph, but bow to your desire and let you leave it. out.

They have been copying my "Coal Picker" in a great many papers, I see. The last one I received is the "Boston American," and to my great regret they never mentioned the fact that it appeared in "Poetry." I have written them a letter and blown them up about it.

Did I tell you that I met a man in London who was perfectly delighted with my "Vers Libre and Metrical Prose" article? He said it told him what he had always wanted to know and had never been able to find in English.
Do read my "London Letter" in the October "Little Review." It has nothing to do with poetry, but I think it may interest you. You do not answer me about reviewing Mr. Frost's book.
That name is Mrs. TC.heodore Amussen.
Please don't think I am a horrid disagreeable thing. I do take a great many of your suggestions, you know. Have you forgiven me?

back.note: Lowell's review of Grace Fallow Norton's The Sister of the Wind was published in Poetry, Vol. 5, No. 2 (November, 1914) 87-88.
